Introduction

Ludwig angina (

Ludwig angina
) is rapidly progressive cellulitis involving the submandibular, sublingual, and submental spaces that make up the floor of the mouth.  Most cases arise from dental infections in the mandibular molars.  Symptoms include fever, mouth pain, drooling, dysphagia, and muffled voice.  Life-threatening airway obstruction can occur because submandibular edema causes enlargement and elevation of the tongue.  CT scan of the neck confirms the diagnosis, and treatment is broad-spectrum antibiotics.

Anatomy



There are 3 potential spaces within the mandibular aspect of the neck:



  • Submandibular space:  bordered anteriorly and laterally by the mandible, medially by the digastric muscles, inferiorly by the hyoid bone, and superiorly by the mylohyoid muscle
  • Sublingual space:  located just superior to the submandibular space, between the tongue (superior border) and mylohyoid muscle (inferior border)
  • Submental space:  located anterior and inferior to the submandibular space and separated from the submandibular space by the anterior digastric muscle, which forms the posterior border

Risk factors



  • Dental infections, particularly involving the second and third mandibular molars, are the most common predisposing factor.  Poor oral hygiene, dental procedures (eg, root canal), and a history of dental caries or periodontal disease increase the risk for dental infections.
  • Mandible fracture.
  • Peritonsillar/parapharyngeal abscess.
  • Submandibular sialadenitis (inflammation/infection of the submandibular salivary gland).


Comorbid medical conditions (eg, immunocompromise, diabetes mellitus, malnutrition), smoking, and alcohol overuse also increase risk.

Pathophysiology



Ludwig angina is usually caused by a polymicrobial infection with a mixture of aerobic (eg, viridans streptococci) and anaerobic (eg, Fusobacterium) bacteria from the oral flora.



Most cases arise from odontogenic infections that spread contiguously to the tooth root, which is located in the submandibular space.  Bacteria then move by direct extension into adjacent sublingual and submental spaces.  Infection and inflammation tend to progress rapidly.



Edema within the submandibular area causes elevation of the floor of the mouth and upward displacement of the tongue, which can quickly result in airway occlusion.  The inflammation may extend to adjacent airway structures (eg, epiglottis), further increasing the risk for respiratory compromise.  If not treated promptly, infection can migrate further into deep neck spaces (eg, retropharyngeal) or the mediastinum.

Clinical presentation



Patients with Ludwig angina often present with rapidly progressive symptoms.



  • Systemic symptoms:  fever, chills, fatigue
  • Localized symptoms:  mouth pain, dysphagia, muffled voice, drooling, stiff neck, possibly trismus
  • Airway compromise:  tripod positioning, stridor, tachypnea


Examination findings are often striking due to the mass effect from edema:



  • Symmetric swelling and induration of the bilateral submandibular region, leading to a characteristic "woody" induration and "bull neck"
  • Elevation of the floor of the mouth
  • Tongue enlargement
  • Tenderness on palpation of the submandibular area and oral floor
  • Lymphadenopathy is typically absent (characteristic of Ludwig angina)

Diagnosis



Diagnosis of Ludwig angina is based primarily on clinical evaluation and history of a recent dental infection or procedure.



Laboratory evaluation is not particularly helpful.  Although a complete blood count may reveal leukocytosis, it is not specific to this condition.  Blood cultures should be obtained to rule out bacteremia, but additional laboratory work-up is typically unnecessary.



Imaging studies, including CT scan or MRI of the neck, should be performed to confirm the diagnosis and assess the extent of soft tissue involvement.  Imaging can also help identify potential complications such as abscess or extension of infection into the deep neck spaces.

Differential diagnosis



  • Cervical lymphadenitis:  inflammation and enlargement of cervical lymph nodes that can cause tenderness and induration in the neck.  However, it does not lead to swelling of the mouth floor, tongue displacement, or airway obstruction, and it is typically associated with upper respiratory (not dental) infections.
  • Acute epiglottitis (
    figure 2
    ):  possible life-threatening airway obstruction and presentation with sore throat, fever, muffled voice, and drooling.  However, it does not cause submandibular induration or tongue elevation.
  • Peritonsillar abscess (
    figure 3
    ):  a collection of pus between the tonsil and the pharyngeal muscles.  Peritonsillar abscess can present with severe sore throat, fever, odynophagia, and trismus.  However, examination typically shows a unilateral area of tonsillar/palatal swelling with contralateral uvular deviation.  The floor of the mouth is not involved.
  • Retropharyngeal abscess:  an infection involving the potential space posterior to the pharynx.  Clinical presentation includes fever, neck stiffness, dysphagia, and respiratory distress, but retropharyngeal abscess typically occurs in young children.
  • Acute sialadenitis:  inflammation of the salivary glands (typically the submandibular or parotid glands), usually due to duct obstruction by stones.  Patients have swelling, pain, and tenderness localized over the affected gland, and symptoms are often exacerbated by eating.

Management



  • Assessment and protection of the airway are the priorities.  Any respiratory compromise should prompt emergency airway intervention.  Intubation may be extremely difficult due to soft tissue swelling, and tracheostomy may be required.
  • Empiric broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy (eg, ampicillin-sulbactam) should treat both aerobic and anaerobic oral flora.
  • The patient should be admitted to the hospital for close monitoring and symptom control.
  • Surgical intervention may be necessary if a drainable abscess is visible on CT scan, but abscesses usually form later in the clinical course (if at all).

Prognosis



With prompt recognition and appropriate management, the prognosis of Ludwig angina is generally favorable.  Delayed diagnosis or inadequate treatment can lead to severe complications, including airway obstruction, mediastinitis, sepsis, and death.  Close monitoring of patients for signs of clinical improvement and resolution of symptoms is essential for optimal outcomes.

Summary



Ludwig angina is a serious infection of the floor of the mouth that is often related to a dental infection.  Mouth pain, stiff neck, dysphagia, drooling, and fever are typical symptoms.  Characteristic examination findings include elevation of the floor of the mouth and tongue, as well as induration and swelling of the submandibular area.  Airway monitoring and protection (if necessary) and broad-spectrum antibiotics are the mainstays of treatment.
